comments.commentBody: I actually thought the Junior Varsity had a better debate, because there were two adults in the room - Pataki and Graham. Graham upbraided the others about what realistically can be passed in the Senate with zero Democratic support. Pataki was rational about gays being assured that they can receive a marriage license. Graham made a reasonable case for sending U.S. forces into Syria. I disagree strongly, but he made a case. Jindal and Santorum seemed silly at times of course.

I don't disagree with this as a description of Western economies before 2007, though the underlying problems manifested during the late 1970s. As I understand it, the notion of secular stagnation involves bubble-dependent economic prosperity.

No question, too, that European countries have a far more generous social welfare system than the United States. But this reminds me that I ought also to have included the effects of global immigration on living standards in developed countries.
Oy vey - now what? I guess it's going to be Verizon Fios next. Bummer.

It could be "nativist sentiment". But more likely it is suspected fraud. Multiple people living along the Texas border are currently serving time for issuing fraudulent birth records to foreign nationals. It was actually discovered by DHS during the Bush administration when they saw a spike in passport applications with a particular "midwives" listed as birth attendants. They asked Texas authorities to cooperate in an investigation and discovered several "midwives" who were present in multiple places at the same time assisting supposed illegal immigrants with home births. It turned out that they were simply selling birth records for a couple hundred dollars each.

I looked at the history of the 14th Amendment. The truth of the Law of this Amendment that was passed by Congress, during the reconstruction of the South, after the Civil War, was to ensure citizenship for the children born from the African slaves.  The Amendment was written in a "broad language", to ensure that freedom. The Law in its broad language was later applied to those, who came to the United States "illegally", and had their children--therefore using them to fight deportation, because they are "American Citizens." Immigration Lawyers would fight to keep the families together. There have been failed past attempts in Congress to amend the Law, so the children of illegals, would not have automatic citizenship, but it would be squashed by the "special interests." Therefore--Texas is doing on a state level, what Congress will not do on the Federal level.
Just goes to show that big companies can always buy their way out.

Martha Stewart went to jail for six months for lying about a stock trade. But David Petraeus gave top secret documents to his lover and got probation, and now GM, who only admitted to the serious defect after a private investigator took apart one of the faulty ignition switches, gets to walk away from criminally negligent homicide by writing a check.

Every time I think my cynicism has maxed out, I'm proved wrong.
It is sad, very sad when there is no accountability when uncalled-for death of people occurs; however, your recommendation on what I wrote makes me feel somewhat hopeful. Thank you.

“Corporations can only commit crimes through flesh-and-blood people,” Sally Q. Yates, the deputy attorney general and the author of the memo, said in an interview on Wednesday. “It’s only fair that the people who are responsible for committing those crimes be held accountable. The public needs to have confidence that there is one system of justice and it applies equally"

So what happened in those few weeks that changed the Government's Policy?
Here, here! Just curious, what happens to all the money collected via these various hollow "judgements?"

If corporations are people and can contribute to campaign contributions unlimited, then corporations can also be charged with murder. The willful murder of 124 people in the name of profit.

The fact that GM just bought their way out of the deaths of 124 people with money with no one even going to jail speak volumes of how corrupt and ineffectual our justice and legal system has become.

Seems successive Atty Generals and US Attorney's have conveniently forgotten concept of "Respondeat Superior".. The notion that the top dog in an org ..aka ceo in a corp ( artificial creature created by statute not devine conception ) is responsible for the acts of his/her agents?

All the double talk by doj why they couldn't charge any individual criminally doesn't pass the smell test..such simple application of rule: mr/ms ceo reason u r paid so much is that u have much responsibility...including going to jail if u permit criminal acts on your watch...what part of this notion so difficult to enforce..not retroactive .concept long known..whole corporate law built on this notion

Another company gets off with no admission of guilt. Many executives still at GM knew about this problem for years and they did nothing while people died. They are guilty. The public should be outraged with this settlement.
@ThomasZaslavsky, Not all of them do, no doubt, but many do.
Unfortunately citizenship is usually the first and foremost thing on their minds, TZ.
Those people don't usually cross a border at 8 months pregnant to have a baby in a foreign country. These are not accidents, it is an attempt to break the law and get a free ride, plain and simple.

It's a sneaky practice that should not have been, and it's wrong to deny anyone their birth certificate. That said, a newborn to make the argument, and it falls to the parents to do so, which makes it a perfect roundabout way to deny the baby's right by denying the adult. Whoever thought this policy out deserves a genius award for creativity.

That said, 14th amendment notwithstanding, I've always found the issue with anchor baby rather distasteful, to put it mildly. It's not an issue with the babies, per se, but I find it rather repulsive the way in which their parents would use the babies as a means to finagle their way into this country to eventually gain residency.

It seems when the Supreme Court made corporations people they failed to define the legal responsibilities that new status requires.  Manslaughter is what happened and the employees were agents of G.M.

This is a no-brainer. Years of hiding and covering up by lawyers and executives, faulty designs attributed to engineers who created the problem and then never corrected it. Each and every one of these individuals has been identified by what they did and when they did it, unlike other crimes where the evidence may not be so clear.

Yet in spite of this, our government can let these people walk and not pay anything for their behavior. Something is truly wrong with our government prosecutors. Their actions just feed into the Republican talking points of an incompetent government. The government attorney prosecuting this should be ashamed to let these criminals walk away.

Where is the principal of fairness in all of this? Really shameful.

I see your point to a point, but the fact is that the quotas for immigrants for some countries are more than enough to meat the demand whereas an aspiring immigrant from Central America or Mexico would have to wait most of his or her whole life to come accept the low-wage jobs here that he or she is willing to do and that few Americans are.  We should be thanking them for picking our apples and cleaning our toilets and shopping in our stores rather than persecuting them for keeping our economy afloat.

Can you say U.S. citizen, according to our Constitution?  Regardless of how you define their parents, most of whom have committed at most a misdemeanor by violating some visa law, any child born in the U.S. has the Constitutional right to his or her birth certificate and social security number, not to mention vaccinations, health care, school, employment.

Those are good ideas, and which I would support, provided that we first set out on the right foot, and that is, that to begin with, anyone on our soil be here legally. I would not have a discussion about bestowing any rights on anyone who is here illegally. As Mr. Trumps has said, "they need to go back."

There is no problem with our current policy of birth-right citizenship.
We do have a problem with haters.

I'd like to see someone come up with a sensible immigration policy -- i.e. one that neither stirs up xenophobia nor allows for unregulated immigration to this country. Like others commenting, I'm usually fairly liberal but even as an immigrant-now-naturalized-US-citizen, I can see problems occurring with our current policy. If no one on the left comes up with something workable, we are left with non-workable xenophobic plans Trump's.

Here are some thoughts:
(1) Do away with citizenship based merely on where the baby is born; base it instead on the parents' citizenship status. If one parent is a citizen (native or naturalized), regardless of where the child is born, that child is automatically a US citizen (that's how it works right now anyway).
(2) Current illegal Immigrants do serve a purpose in the national economy. Figure out a way for them to work here legally but with limited status.
(3) Limit the number of children the US will support for people here with work permits. E.g. two children at most, after that, the family is on the hook for everything else. I think many immigrants would be happy for their kids to have a chance to grow up in the US that even limited benefits would be seen as great but we don't need to give them everything.
I find offensive your implication that the parent's status negates a citizen's right to his or her birth certificate.
Except very few countries honor this "universal human right." We're one of the few that tolerate it.

Don't worry Vlad, thanks to the illegal immigrants you so love we will soon have a 3rd world paradise just like North Korea complete with a strongman. Start singing your songs to praise dear leader, Obama was just a warm up.

That's what I've been counting on -- replacing the Social Security collections from lots of retiring aerospace workers with the pittances collected from illegal carwasheros and grape pickers.

If school for one illegal immigrant's child cost $10,000 a year, let's run a few numbers. So, they don't pay any income tax. Sales tax at even 10% would require them to spend $100,000 a year on sales taxable items. Um, no. If someone drives 15,000 miles a year and get 20 miles a gallon, they buy 750 gallons of gas. Tax on that comes to maybe $375. They don't come close to paying for themselves.

Everyone has a right to live in the place where they were born free from persecution. Period. End of story. This is a basic human right that a significant fraction of western democracies seem to be ignoring but thankfully is enshrined in our Constitution.

A second important part of our democracy is that we do not punish children for their parents' mistakes. Do you know who does that? North Korea.
On my father's, some guy hopped a boat before the year 1800. No visa required.

Taxation is one aspect of US jurisdiction that applies to US citizens abroad, but not to "anyone" in the US who is neither a citizen nor a legal resident. But I think you're right – though the point remains that the 14th Amendment cares neither about the foreign citzenship of parents (potentially unless they are diplomats) nor of the child, in cases where the child acquires not just one, but several citizenships at birth (US by physical presence, others through the parents' nationality).

The words "subject to the jurisdiction thereof" has meaning. Illegal aliens are still subject to their respective countries laws; both the ~60% from south of the border and the 40% from elsewhere. In particular this would impact the anchor baby people that return back to the home country after birth. Where does their allegiance lie?

If the parents are in the country illegally, can not legally work, can not access entitlements for themselves, in other words cannot legally support a child, how can it possibly make sense for the child to be considered a US citizen?!

The 14th Amendment says anyone born in the United States AND of parents who are not subject to the jurisdiction of a foreign nation, are US citizens. Both conditions are required. Citizens of foreign nations are subject to the jurisdiction of those nations and not of the United States; the 14th Amendment disqualifies children of parents who are not subject to the jurisdiction of the US. Those who claim that "anyone born in the United States is a US citizen" are ignoring the plain words of the 14th Amendment. That second requirement has never been nullified by any other amendment or any SCOTUS ruling.

My birth certificate was issued in the state of Texas.
I sure hope my personal info is not handed over to just anyone. I'm sure you all might feel the same way where ever you live.
As far as I'm concerned, proper identification is the right thing. I can't expect anything more and I don't look favorably on these whiners.
what is the point of referencing another time in the past? the reality of today is different.

Dp you want everyone and their cousin coming here on your dime overpopulating this country? The easier it gets for illegals the more who will come and then demand in our social services. Just look at Europe and the Syrian mess going on now. People think they are entitled to just go anywhere they wish now. That is wrong. Obey the laws.

Did they ask you of your when you checked into the hospital to delivery a baby? Did they ask you of any insurance info? If not, and if you're a US taxpayer, you should ask yourself, why not?

Ultimately the money (for the hospital and the public service that you've enjoyed) has to come from somewhere. Surely far left liberals are going to throw the 14th amendment when I say this, but this is a matter of fairness to me. For anyone to cross the border, and then walk in to demand the same rights and all the services and benefits that local residents work hard to pay for, that just does not sit right with me. Yes, I digress from the topic in this article, but I have to get this out of my system.

In general, I consider myself a bit left leaning, but mostly middle-of-the-road. But this is the kind of issue, the same kind of attitude that illegal migrants that rush the shore in Europe who DEMAND their rights from a different country simply because they can't, that gets me peeved every so often.

And, neither your driver's license or your health insurance card proved that you were a US citizen.

Exactly how many generations of birth certificates should parents have to show to "prove" that their new-borns are citizens?

When my children were born in NYC, no one asked me for any identification.  The only requirement was that I had to name the baby before we left the hospital, if the name was to be on the birth certificate.  A copy of the certificate came in the mail within a few weeks.  Why shouldn't it be this simple anywhere?

They're not immigrants. They're illegal aliens. And those babies are not necessarily US citizens either.

The Fourteenth Amendment was passed to prevent the former slave states from disenfranchising and abusing the rights of black Americans. The current interpretation, that anchor babies and birth tourist babies are US citizens because their parents arranged to have them born here, is self destructive.

We have ourselves to blame. When we're finished blaming ourselves, we can fix the problem. The Texas government actions described in this article will end up in a Supreme Court challenge and, one can hope, a workable interpretation of the Fourteenth Amendment.

As we are seeing in Europe and on our own borders, mobile communications and social media facilitate unwanted migrations, masses of unknown and often unsuitable candidates for citizenship. Desperate and unhappy people all over the world are watching the Moslem migration in Europe. We simply cannot allow our hard-won civil liberties to become millstones around our necks.

Again punishing a baby for the actions of his/her parents.  We can either be unwelcoming, belligerent, xenophobic tough guys, or charitable, welcoming, guys who step up to help the less fortunate when we can.  I don't want to think of the American people as a bunch of hostile jerks who made it in the world and then pulled up the ladder behind us.
